questions.text: The Prostate gland in males and the Paraurethral glands in females are derivatives of which embryonic structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Urogenital sinus

 

Explanation:

The prostate glands in males & their homologous counterparts, the paraurethral glands (Skene’s gland) in females, both develop from the Urogenital sinus.
It’s a structure that forms during early embryonic development and gives rise to various parts of the urinary and reproductive systems.

 

Embryonic Structure

Dihydrotestosterone

  • Sertoli cells

  • Ventral aspect of the penis
  • The floor of the penile urethra

Genital tubercle

Clitoris

Glans penis

Urogenital sinus

(Option C)
  • Urinary bladder, Urethra
  • Lower 1/5th of vagina
  • Paraurethral(Skene’s) glands
  • Greater(Bartholin) and lesser vestibular glands
  • Vestibule
  • Urinary bladder, Urethra
  • Prostatic utricle
  • Prostate gland
  • Bulbourethral glands

(Paramesonephric duct)

questions.text: A 34y/o woman reports a painless swelling in the right outer vaginal area. Examination reveals a smooth, non-tender, cystic swelling at the posterior vaginal opening near the right labia majora with no inflammation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bartholin’s gland cyst

Explanation:

The presentation is consistent with Bartholin's Gland Cyst, which results from the obstruction of Bartholin's gland duct.

  • Cyst characteristics: Painless, smooth, cystic swelling in the inferior labia majora or posterior vestibule near the fourchette.
  • Gland characteristics: Bilateral, 0.5 to 1 cm in diameter, located deep to vestibular bulb and bulbospongiosus muscle.
  • Complication: Infection can lead to abscess formation.
  • Common Pathogens: E. coli, gram-positive/negative aerobes, anaerobes.

Clinical Features:

  • Unnoticed when small.
  • Larger cysts cause local discomfort and dyspareunia.
  • Unilateral swelling on posterior labium majora, projecting medially, making vulvar cleft 'S'-shaped.

Treatment:

  • Small, asymptomatic cysts require no intervention except exclusion of neoplasia in women >40 years.
  • Symptomatic cysts are managed by incision and drainage (I&D), marsupialization, or Bartholin gland excision.


 

Gartner's duct cyst ( Option A): Remnant of Wolffian duct located along the anterolateral vaginal walls. Mostly asymptomatic; detected incidentally. If large, it can cause discomfort, urinary issues, or dyspareunia; hence, it is surgically removed.

 

Skene's Duct Cyst (Option C): Occurs due to obstruction of Skene's glands near the urethral meatus. They are located at the sides of the urethral meatus, not near the vaginal opening, ruling them out.

 

Nabothian cyst (Option D): Nabothian cysts are benign cysts that develop on the cervix due to blocked cervical glands. They appear as smooth, clear, pale white or yellow rounded elevations on the cervix. They are not located in the labium majora and do not present as a swelling near the vaginal opening.

questions.text: A 20 year old woman comes with complaints of cyclic pelvic pain but no menstrual bleeding. She reports normal breast development and pubic hair growth. Physical examination reveals a blind-ending vaginal pouch. An ultrasound confirms the presence of hematocolpos, hematometra, and normal ovaries. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Transverse vaginal septum

Explanation:

The given case scenario is suggestive of Transverse vaginal septum, a vertical fusion defect presenting as cryptomenorrhea (hidden menstruation).

In cryptomenorrhea, menstruation occurs but is not expelled due to an obstruction of the outflow tract. It comprises of:

  • Hematocolpos (distension of vagina with blood)
  • Hematometra (distension of the uterus with blood)
  • Hematosalpinx (distension of fallopian tubes with blood)

 

Vertical fusion defects :

  • Transverse vaginal septum
  • Imperforate hymen
  • Vaginal atresia
  • Cervico vaginal atresia
  • Mullerian agenesis

Aspect

Transverse vaginal septum

(Option C)

Imperforate hymen

(Option B)

Etiology

Vertical fusion defect or faulty canalization of urogenital sinus and Müllerian ducts

Failure of central cells of Müllerian eminence to disintegrate projecting into the urogenital sinus. Faulty canalization but not a fusion defect

Location

It can occur in the upper (45%), middle (40%), or lower (15%) vagina

Located at the vaginal opening.

Clinical features

Primary amenorrhea, pelvic pain, urinary symptoms, hematocolpos, hematometra, a pinkish concave covering seen

Primary amenorrhea, cyclic abdominal pain, hematocolpos, hematometra, and a bluish convex bulge (cryptomenorrhea)

Diagnostic tools

Clinical examination, USG, MRI

Clinical examination, USG

Treatment

A surgical incision to remove the septum may require an abdominovaginal approach if complex, and vaginoplasty may be needed

Cruciate incision to release menstrual blood - leads to normal reproductive function

Diagrammatic Representation

VAGINAL SEPTUM" data-author="na" data-hash="354" data-license="na" data-source="na" data-tags="December2024" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/6OldTHydj2QvxNXg7IWA1734631487.png" />

 
  • Vaginal atresia is a condition where the lower part of the vagina is replaced by fibrous tissue, while the adjacent upper structures, such as the uterus, are well developed.
  • Mullerian agenesis is failure of the Müllerian ducts to develop, resulting in congenital absence of the uterus and the upper two-thirds of the vagina, while the ovaries and external genitalia are normal.

Asherman Syndrome (Option A): This condition causes intrauterine adhesions, usually after surgery or infection, resulting in amenorrhea. Patients typically lack cyclic pelvic pain or hematocolpos due to improper shedding of the endometrial lining.

 

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) (Option D): PCOS features irregular or absent menstrual cycles, hirsutism, and polycystic ovaries on ultrasound. Secondary amenorrhea is common, but cyclic pelvic pain, blind-ending vaginal pouch, or hematocolpos are typically absent.

questions.text: A 19 y/o female presents with primary amenorrhea with normal breast development and pubic hair growth. On physical examination, her external genitalia are normal but the vaginal canal is shorter than usual. A USG reveals the absence of the uterus and upper two-thirds of the vagina, but the ovaries are present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) Syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • The case scenario is consistent with MRKH Syndrome.
  • Failure of the Müllerian ducts to develop, resulting in congenital absence of the uterus and the upper two-thirds of the vagina, while the ovaries and external genitalia are normal.
  • Also known as Mullerian agenesis or complete vaginal agenesis.

 

Complete Vaginal Agenesis (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome)

Definition
  • Developmental defects of the Müllerian ducts result in the absence of structures derived from them, namely the uterus, cervix, and upper vagina.
  • Normal ovaries and external genitalia.

Clinical Presentation
  • Primary amenorrhea.
  • Examination: Shallow vaginal pouch measuring 1–2 cm in length.
  • Phenotypic Sex: Female, with normal breast development, body proportions, hair distribution, and external genitalia.
  • Genetic Sex: Female (46, XX karyotype).
  • Associated with skeletal and spine abnormalities (20%-30%) and urological abnormalities like malrotation of kidneys, ectopic kidneys (e.g., horseshoe kidney, pelvic kidney).

Diagnosis
  • Imaging: Pelvic and abdominal ultrasound, 3D ultrasound, and MRI.
  • Karyotyping. 

Differential Diagnoses
  • Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (CAIS) (Option A): 
    • Karyotype is 46 XY, and testosterone levels are typically in the male range.
    • Normal female external genitalia & breast development.
    • Primary amenorrhea.
    • Lack of uterus or undescended testes (abdomen or inguinal canal).
    • Lack of axillary and pubic hair.
  • Imperforate hymen.
  • Transverse vaginal septum.

Treatment
  • Nonsurgical methods: Frank's method of dilation.
  • Surgical vaginoplasty.

 

Turner Syndrome (Option C): Complete or partial absence of one X chromosome (45, X).

Kallmann Syndrome (Option D): Defective migration of GnRH-producing and olfactory neurons during embryonic development.

questions.text: A 14-y/o girl presents with complaints of cyclic lower abdominal pain for the past 6 months. She has not yet had her menarche. Abdominal examination reveals a palpable mass extending up to the umbilicus. The genital examination shows the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Imperforate Hymen

Explanation:

Imperforate hymen

  • Cause: This congenital condition involves a hymen that completely obstructs the vaginal opening, leading to the accumulation of menstrual blood behind the hymen.
  • Clinical features:
    • Cyclic lower abdominal pain
    • Primary amenorrhea
    • Suprapubic bulge due to Hematocolpos (blood build-up in the uterus)
    • Urinary symptoms- Frequency/Retention/dysuria
    • Tense Blue bulging membrane at vaginal introitus

 

  • Diagnosis: Clinical examination & USG
  • Treatment: Cruciate incision to release menstrual blood - leads to normal reproductive function

 

 

Transverse vaginal septum (Option A) is a congenital anomaly where a horizontal septum forms higher up in the vagina, blocking the vaginal canal. There is no bulging hymenal membrane at the vaginal introitus.


PCOS (Option C) is characterized by irregular menstrual cycles, hirsutism, and polycystic ovaries on ultrasound.

Vaginal Agenesis (MRKH Syndrome) (Option D) involves the absence of the upper 2/3rd of the vagina and the entire uterus. Patients present with primary amenorrhea but do not experience cyclic pain since there is no menstrual blood production.

questions.text: A 32 y/o woman with a history of 3 first-trimester miscarriages and regular menstrual cycles had an HSG showing an indented external uterine contour. MRI confirms two separate endometrial cavities with a partial outer uterine indentation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bicornuate uterus

Explanation:

Differentiating a Bicornuate and Septate Uterus plays a crucial role in arriving at a diagnosis.

  • 3D sonography and MRI provide accurate assessments.

Gold standard- Hysteroscopy + Diagnostic Laparoscopy

SEPTATE UTERUS

(Option A)

Aspect

BICORNUATE UTERUS

(Option B)

<75°, Acute

Intercornual angle

>105°, Obtuse

<4 cm

Distance b/w horns

>4 cm

>5 mm

Distance b/w Endometrium to fundus

<5 mm

Hysteroscopic Septal Resection

Treatment

Strassman or Jone's Metroplasty

Flat/ convex (normal)

Fundal contour (external)

Concave/indented

 

Diagrammatic Representation

 

Septate vs Bicornuate uterus" data-author="Kanna Jayaprakasan, kamal ojha" data-hash="357" data-license="CC" data-source="https://www.mdpi.com/2077-0383/11/5/1251" data-tags="December2024" height="208" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/xykHrd79BDWV990r7PmB1734632279.png" width="506" />

 


Didelphys uterus (Option C) arises from the complete failure of the fusion of the Mullerian ducts, resulting in two separate uterine cavities, each with its cervix. It can also present with two vaginas. On HSG/MRI, two separate uterine bodies with no connection between them are seen.

There is an increased incidence of breech and preterm labor.

Representation

HSG of Didelphys uterus

 

Unicornuate uterus (Option D) is caused by the failure to develop one of the Mullerian ducts. This results in a single uterine cavity and fallopian tube, leading to poor pregnancy outcomes. It appears smaller and curved to one side(banana-shaped), unlike a bicornuate uterus (heart-shaped).

 

 

Representation

HSG of Unicornuate uterus

questions.text: A 16-year-old phenotypic female with primary amenorrhea and absent pubic/axillary hair has normal breast development, eunuchoidal body habitus (long arms, big hands, and feet). Pelvic ultrasound shows absent uterus and ovaries but bilateral testes is present in the inguinal region, and karyotype is 46,XY. What is the most likely condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Testicular Feminization Syndrome

Explanation:

  • Testicular Feminization Syndrome, or Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS), is caused by mutations in the androgen receptor gene (AR), impairing androgen signaling.
  • Individuals with a 46, XY karyotype develop a female phenotype with sparse or absent axillary and pubic hair, normal breast development, and a eunuchoidal body habitus.
  • Internal examination shows absent uterus and ovaries.
  • Testes present in the abdominal/ inguinal or labial region. 

Swyer syndrome (Option C),  also known as Complete Gonadal Dysgenesis, presents with primary amenorrhea, absent secondary sexual characteristics, and having a 46, XY karyotype. Gonads are typically fibrous or streak-like due to incomplete gonadal development unlike testis seen in AIS.

 


Turner syndrome (Option D) results from the complete or partial absence of one X chromosome (45 X or variants), leading to primary amenorrhea, underdeveloped secondary sexual characteristics, short stature, and streak gonads (fibrous ovaries).

questions.text: What is the recommended management for an individual with Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) who is reared as a female?

choices.text: Early gonadectomy and long-term estrogen replacement therapy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Early gonadectomy and long-term estrogen replacement therapy

 

Explanation:

Individuals with AIS who are assigned female at birth have an increased risk of gonadal malignancy (gonadoblastoma or dysgerminoma). Therefore, early removal of the testes (gonadectomy) is recommended. Estrogen replacement therapy is needed to induce and maintain female secondary sexual characteristics and to support vaginal health.


 

Treatment of Testicular Feminization Syndrome

Female Gender Assignment

(Reared as a girl)

Male Gender Assignment

(Conversion as a male)
  • Gonadectomy: Testes (which are ectopic and present in the abdomen or inguinal canal) are typically removed due to the high risk of gonadal malignancy (20-30% risk), specifically gonadoblastoma or dysgerminoma (Option B).
 
  • Timing: Gonadectomy is usually performed at the start of puberty.
 
  • Estrogen Replacement Therapy: After gonadectomy, long-term estrogen therapy is prescribed to induce and maintain secondary sexual characteristics (such as breast development) and for the health of the vaginal epithelium (Option B).
 
  • Vaginoplasty: Reconstruction of the vagina is considered after completion of growth (around 16-18 years of age) to allow for normal sexual function.
  • Surgical and Medical Management: The decision to transition to male involves considerations such as the size of the phallus and the feasibility of constructing a penile urethra (Option C).
 
  • Testosterone Therapy: Testosterone is administered to induce virilization and promote the development of male secondary sexual characteristics, including enlargement of the phallus. (Option A)
 
  • Timing: Testosterone therapy may begin before puberty to maximize its effects on phallic growth, especially in cases of 5-alpha reductase deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following compounds is a direct precursor to Testosterone in the adrenal steroidogenesis pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Androstenedione


 

Explanation:

Androstenedione is the immediate precursor to Testosterone. It is converted to Testosterone by the enzyme 17β OH Steroid Dehydrogenase.

Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) (Option A) is an intermediate in the pathway, but it is not the direct precursor to Testosterone. It needs to be converted to Androstenedione first.

 

17 OH Pregnenolone (Option C) is an upstream intermediate in the pathway, leading to the formation of DHEA and, subsequently, Androstenedione, but it is not the direct precursor to Testosterone.

 

Estrone (Option D) is an estrogen and is not involved in the direct biosynthesis of Testosterone. It is a product of the aromatization of Androstenedione.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents to the clinic with concerns about rapid pubertal development. Her parents report that she began developing pubic hair around age 8 and has experienced rapid increase in height over the past year. On physical examination, she has an enlarged clitoris and coarse hair growth on her face, arms and legs. Laboratory examination revealed elevated 17-hydroxy progesterone levels. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

Explanation:

  • In the above clinical scenario, the patient presented with the symptoms of androgen excess including signs of hirsutism, clitoromegaly, and rapid growth.
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia is a group of inherited disorders affecting the adrenal glands.
  • The most common cause is the deficiency of the 21-hydroxylase enzyme, leading to excess production of ACTH and androgens causing peripheral precocious puberty.
  • Non classic form of CAH presents in the adolescent female with the above-mentioned symptoms.
  • 17-hydroxy progesterone, substrate of the enzyme 21-hydroxylase is accumulated in the blood and used in the diagnosis.

 

Premature thelarche (Option A): Early development of breast tissue in girls, typically before the age of 8, without other signs of puberty. It is seen due to excess estrogens, not androgens.

Central precocious puberty(Option C): In central precocious puberty, puberty begins earlier than usual due to the premature activation of the HPG axis. CAH is a cause of peripheral precocious puberty, not central.

Turner syndrome (Option D) is caused by a severe structural abnormality of one X chromosome in a phenotypic female (45X0). It is the most common form of gonadal dysgenesis that leads to primary ovarian insufficiency. Secondary sexual development is absent; ambiguous genitalia- not present.

questions.text: A 16 y/o female presents to the clinic with primary amenorrhea and lack of secondary sexual characteristics. Physical examination reveals normal female external genitalia but no breast development. Karyotype analysis shows a 46, XY genotype. Further investigation indicates the presence of streak gonads. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Swyer Syndrome

 

Explanation:

Swyer syndrome is a male pseudohermaphrodite, a pure 46 XY gonadal dysgenesis with the presence of a uterus and a cervix but with hypoestrogenism and poorly developed breasts. Undeveloped testes do not secrete testosterone and Mullerian inhibiting factors resulting in the development of female genital organs and female phenotype.

 

Turner Syndrome(Option B): It usually involves a 45, X karyotype and is characterized by features such as short stature and a webbed neck. The presence of a 46, XY karyotype does not fit Turner syndrome.

 

Mixed Gonadal dysgenesis (Option C): This typically involves a 45XO/46XY mosaic karyotype and ambiguous genitalia. The presence of normal female external genitalia and a 46, XY karyotype suggests Swyer syndrome rather than mixed gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS)(Option D): AIS involves a 46, XY karyotype, female external genitalia, and typically well-developed breasts due to the body's insensitivity to androgens. The absence of breast development and the presence of streak gonads are inconsistent with AIS.

 

Diagnosis

Turner’s Syndrome

Mixed Gonadal Dysgenesis

Swyer Syndrome

Clinical Presentation
  • Primary amenorrhea
  • Poor secondary sexual characters
  • Short stature
  • Webbing of neck
  • Cubitus valgus
  • Underdeveloped genitalia

At birth: Ambiguous sex

 

At Puberty:

  • Virilism with amenorrhea
  • External genitalia: partial masculinisation
  • Internal genitalia may have unilateral Mullerian development
  • Amenorrhea
  • Secondary sex characteristics absent
  • Female external genitalia

Diagnostic Criteria
  • Karyotype 45, XO
  • Bilateral streak gonads
  • Serum:E2 ￬and FSH ￪
  • Karyotype : 45 X0 / 46 XY
  • Gonads: Testis on one side and on the other side a ‘streak’
  • Karyotype 46 XY
  • Fibrous gonadal tissues
  • Female internal genitalia

 

Reproductive Outcome

Pregnancy with donor oocyte

Depends on anatomic sex

Rare with IVF and donor oocytes

questions.text: Which of the following options regarding the Barr body is incorrect?

choices.text: In Turner’s syndrome : no barr body

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) In normal male: 1 barr body

Explanation :

Male cell nuclei lack a Barr body and are, therefore, termed chromatin negative. The nuclei of female cells contain one Barr body, and hence, female cells are termed chromatin-positive.

  • A small, peripherally situated, darkly staining nodule in epithelial cell nuclei is called the Barr body.
  • They are DNA condensations of an inactivated X chromosome.
  • A Barr body's presence depends on the presence of the second X chromosome.

 

 

 

Chromosome Karyotype

Number of Barr bodies

45 XO (Turner Syndrome) (Option C)

0

46 XY (Normal Male) (Option A)

0

46XX (Normal Female) (Option B)

1

47 XXY (Klinefelter Syndrome) (Option D)

1
